newsitem.title: COTE D'IVOIRE: African states launch industrial alliance.
newsitem.headline: African states launch industrial alliance.

text.p: African nations banded together on Wednesday in a new alliance to promote industrial development of the world's poorest continent, initially through processing its agricultural and mineral wealth.

The U.N. sponsored Alliance for Africa's Industrialisation, grouping nations from across Sub-Saharan Africa, aims to mobilise investment and help plug the continent into the world information and technological revolution.
But those represented by presidents and prime ministers at the launch in Ivory Coast's commercial capital Abidjan came mainly from Francophone West and Central Africa.
"It's time for the lions and the elephants of Africa to break free of their economic constraints," the head of the U.N. Industrial Development Organisation (UNIDO) told the launch.
Mauricio De Maria Y Campos, whose organisation sponsored the Alliance, said that through it Africa "is issuing a challenge to itself and the outside world".
The Alliance is an idea which took shape in Cameroon in July at the 1996 Organisation of African Unity summit, which approved the principle.

African industry ministers are to draw up plan of action with the private sector at a meeting in Ghana's capital Accra in May 1997. The plan will be presented to the next OAU annual summit in Zimbabwe in 1997.
The launch followed a two-day ministerial meeting on Monday and Tuesday and a two-day meeting last week of experts from member states, who in theory include all the OAU's members.
Ivorian President Henri Konan Bedie, in a launching address in the conference centre of one of Abidjan's leading hotels, expressed optimism in the future of the continent.
"We can affirm without risk of contradiction that the industrialisation of Africa is unstoppable and will enable the continent to take off economically," he said.

An Abidjan Declaration, read by Ivory Coast's minister for planning and industrial development, Theophile Ahoua N'Doli, said that the Alliance was designed to give Africa fresh impetus to drive its economy into the 21st century.

Presidents Omar Bongo of Gabon, Pascal Lissouba of Congo, Alpha Oumar Konare of Mali, Ahmad Tejan Kabbah of Sierra Leone and Ibrahim Bare Mainassara of Niger attended the ceremony as did the prime ministers of Burkina Faso, Guinea, Equatorial Guinea, Chad and Togo.

Ministers or ambassadors from other members were also present. They included Botswana, Cameroon, Central African Republic, Eritrea, Ghana, Lesotho, Madagascar, Mozambique, Nigeria, Rwanda, Senegal, Tanzania, and Nigeria. South Africa was represented by its ambassador.
